item.title: Jenni add a quote by Elizabeth Gilbert
item.description: "There's no trouble in this world so serious that it can't be cured with a hot bath, a glass of whiskey, and the Book of Common Prayer." -- Elizabeth Gilbert

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Jane Kenyon
item.description:
"To the bottle in the ditch, to the scoop in the oats, to air in the lung let evening come.
Let it come, as it will, and don't be afraid. God does not leave us comfortless, so let evening come." -- Jane Kenyon

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Annie Dillard
item.description: "How we spend our days is, of course, how we spend our lives." -- Annie Dillard

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Graham Greene
item.description: "You cannot conceive, nor can I, of the appalling strangeness of the mercy of God." -- Graham Greene

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Walter Wangerin, Jr
item.description: "Mirrors that hide nothing hurt me. But this is the hurt of purging and precious renewal - and these are the mirrors of dangerous grace." -- Walter Wangerin, Jr

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Kathleen Norris
item.description: "If grace is so wonderful, why do we have such difficulty recognizing and accepting it? Maybe it's because grace is not gentle or made-to-order. It often comes disguised as loss, or failure, or unwelcome change." -- Kathleen Norris

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Gustave Flaubert
item.description: "Be steady and well-ordered in your life so that you can be fierce and original in your work." -- Gustave Flaubert

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Madeleine L'Engle
item.description: "We do learn and develop when we are exposed to those who are greater than we are. Perhaps this is the chief way we mature." -- Madeleine L'Engle

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Madeleine L'Engle
item.description: "Love of music, of sunsets and sea; a liking for the same kind of people; political opinions that are not radically divergent; a similar stance as we look at the stars and think of the marvelous strangeness of the universe - these are what build a marriage. And it is never to be taken for granted." -- Madeleine L'Engle

item.title: Jenni add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "It is a good rule after reading a new book, never to allow yourself another new one till you have read an old one in between." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Jenni add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "I seemed to hear God saying, "Put down your gun and we'll talk." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Flannery O'Connor
item.description: "When there is a tendency to compartmentalize the spiritual and make it resident in a certain type of life only, the spiritual is apt gradually to be lost." -- Flannery O'Connor

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Marcel Proust
item.description: "Reading is at the threshold of the spiritual life; it can introduce us to it. It does not constitute it ... There are certain cases of spiritual depression in which reading can become a sort of curative discipline ... reintroducing a lazy mind into the life of the Spirit." -- Marcel Proust

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Marva J. Dawn
item.description: "A great benefit of Sabbath keeping is that we learn to let God take care of us — not by becoming passive and lazy, but in the freedom of giving up our feeble attempts to be God in our own lives." -- Marva J. Dawn

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Laura Bramon Good
item.description: "The longer I pursue a double life, seeking justice in my day job and beauty in reading and writing, the more I’m convinced that justice without joy is as heartless as bureaucracy, and that beauty hoarded for the beautiful is an oppressor’s dream." -- Laura Bramon Good

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Gerard Manley Hopkins
item.description: "Let Him easter in us, be a dayspring to the dimness of us, be a crimson-cresseted east." -- Gerard Manley Hopkins

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Leif Enger
item.description: "Real miracles bother people, like strange sudden pains unknown in medical literature. It's true: They rebut every rule all we good citizens take comfort in. Lazarus obeying orders and climbing up out of the grave - now there's a miracle, and you can bet it upset a lot of folks who were standing around at the time. When a person dies, the earth is generally unwilling to cough him back up. A miracle contradicts the will of the earth." -- Leif Enger

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "I was working on the proof of one of my poems all the morning, and took out a comma. In the afternoon I put it back again." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Leif Enger
item.description: "Listening to Dad's guitar, halting yet lovely in the search for phrasing, I thought: Fair is whatever God wants to do." -- Leif Enger

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Flannery O'Connor
item.description: "There is something in us, as storytellers and as listeners to stories, that demands the redemptive act, that demands that what falls at least be offered the chance to be restored. The reader of today looks for this motion, and rightly so, but what he has forgotten is the cost of it. His sense of evil is diluted or lacking altogether, and so he has forgotten the price of restoration. When he reads a novel, he wants either his sense tormented or his spirits raised. He wants to be transported, instantly, either to mock damnation or a mock innocence." -- Flannery O'Connor

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Flannery O'Connor
item.description: "The writer should never be ashamed of staring. There is nothing that does not require his attention." -- Flannery O'Connor

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Annie Dillard
item.description: "A schedule defends from chaos and whim. A net for catching days." -- Annie Dillard

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Annie Dillard
item.description: "What a hideout: Holiness lies spread and borne over the surface of time and stuff like color." -- Annie Dillard

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Annie Dillard
item.description: "He is careful of what he reads, for that is what he will write. He is careful of what he learns, for that is what he will know." -- Annie Dillard

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Annie Dillard
item.description: "The silence is all there is. It is the alpha and the omega, it is God's brooding over the face of the waters; it is the blinded note of the ten thousand things, the whine of wings. You take a step in the right direction to pray to this silence, and even to address the prayer to "World." Distinctions blur. Quit your tents. Pray without ceasing." -- Annie Dillard

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Frederick Buechner
item.description: "Here is the world. Beautiful and terrible things will happen. Don't be afraid." -- Frederick Buechner

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Frederick Buechner
item.description: "If we are to love our neighbors, before doing anything else we must see our neighbors. With our imagination as well as our eyes, that is to say like artists, we must see not just their faces but the life behind and within their faces. Here it is love that is the frame we see them in." -- Frederick Buechner

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Madeleine L'Engle
item.description: "In reading we must become creators." -- Madeleine L'Engle

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Flannery O'Connor
item.description: "The truth does not change according to our ability to stomach it." -- Flannery O'Connor

item.title: Jenni add a quote by Marilynne Robinson
item.description: "It has seemed to me sometimes as though the Lord breathes on this poor gray ember of Creation and it turns to radiance - for a moment or a year or the span of a life. And then it sinks back into itself again, and to look at it no one would know it had anything to do with fire, or light .... Wherever you turn your eyes the world can shine like transfiguration. You don't have to bring a thing to it except a little willingness to see. Only, who could have the courage to see it? .... Theologians talk about a prevenient grace that precedes grace itself and allows us to accept it. I think there must also be a prevenient courage that allows us to be brave - that is, to acknowledge that there is more beauty than our eyes can bear, that precious things have been put into our hands and to do nothing to honor them is to do great harm." -- Marilynne Robinson
